We have lots of mentors and so you have lots of opportunities to get perspectives from individuals, so feel free to ask your mentor question and if they don't know, they'll just tell you that and they'll help you find someone who does know the answer to your question.

You obviously don't necessarily need to do with your mentor, says your mentor is giving you advice and it's advice that you should consider, but you should also seek advice from other staff members and from other people that are important in your life before you decide you know what to do with, whether to act on it.
You don't need to be in the same science field as your mentor.
Certainly part of mentoring may involve science specific questions.

If you're worried about publications, it's probably helpful to talk to someone in the same field, but there are certainly going to be technical questions that span fields and these broader questions right.

These questions about kind of life and career and family and where you're going are questions that anybody in academia is going to have a perspective on for you, not necessarily just someone in your field.

You mentioned probably won't have been in the exact same position that you've been in, but they've seen a lot of people, and in some cases they've also mentored a lot of people who may have been in your position and their experience and wisdom.
They're going to be able to offer you advice, even if they haven't been in your exact position before.
And finally, peer mentoring can also be very effective.
